title: ES6 Practice Set — From Beginner to Expert
author: Sukanta Hui · Coder & AccoTax Barrackpore

questions.q: Which one is TRUE about let?
questions.explanation: let is always block scoped, unlike var which is function scoped.

questions.q: What will be the output of: console.log(typeof Symbol())?
questions.explanation: ES6 introduced symbol as a new primitive datatype.

questions.q: Template literals allow:
questions.explanation: Template literals support multi-line text and ${} interpolation.

questions.q: Which operator creates a copy of an array?
questions.explanation: The spread operator expands or copies iterable values.

questions.q: What will be logged: console.log([..."ABC"])?
questions.explanation: Strings are iterable; spread breaks them into characters.

questions.q: Which declaration does NOT allow reassignment?
questions.explanation: Variables declared with const cannot be reassigned.

questions.q: What happens if you access a let variable before declaration?
questions.explanation: let and const are in the Temporal Dead Zone before declaration.

questions.q: Which of the following is a valid arrow function?
questions.explanation: Arrow functions use => with parameter list in parentheses.

questions.q: Arrow functions do NOT have their own:
questions.explanation: Arrow functions inherit this from their surrounding lexical scope.

questions.q: Which is TRUE about const with objects?
questions.explanation: const prevents reassignment but properties of objects can still change.

questions.q: Which syntax correctly defines a default parameter?
questions.explanation: ES6 default parameters are defined using = in the parameter list.

questions.q: Which is NOT a feature of template literals?
questions.explanation: Template literals remove the need for + in most string concatenations.

questions.q: Which is valid destructuring of an array?
questions.explanation: Array destructuring uses [ ] brackets.

questions.q: Which is valid object destructuring?
questions.explanation: Object destructuring uses { } with property names.

questions.q: Which statement is TRUE about spread and rest?
options: Both must be used only in arrays
Spread expands values, rest collects values
Spread collects values, rest expands values
questions.answer: Spread expands values, rest collects values
questions.explanation: Spread expands into separate values, rest groups them into an array.

questions.q: What does the rest parameter syntax look like?
questions.explanation: Rest parameters are declared using ... followed by a name.

questions.q: Which keyword is used to export a function from a module?
questions.explanation: export exposes a function, variable, or class from a module.

questions.q: How do you import a default export?
questions.explanation: Default exports are imported without { } and can use any name.

questions.q: Which is a correct named import?
questions.explanation: Named imports use { } with the exported identifier name.

questions.q: What is the typeof an arrow function?
questions.explanation: Arrow functions are still functions and typeof returns 'function'.

questions.q: Which of these is NOT an ES6 feature?
questions.explanation: alert existed long before ES6.

questions.q: Which will correctly clone an object person?
questions.explanation: Spread with {...} creates a shallow copy of an object.

questions.q: What does optional chaining operator look like?
questions.explanation: Optional chaining uses the ?. syntax to safely access nested values.

questions.q: Nullish coalescing operator is used for:
options: Providing default when value is null or undefined
questions.answer: Providing default when value is null or undefined
questions.explanation: ?? returns the right side only if left side is null or undefined.

questions.q: Which for-loop is best for iterating over array values?
questions.explanation: for...of iterates over values of an iterable like array.

questions.q: Which loop is generally NOT recommended for arrays?
questions.explanation: for...in iterates over keys and is more suited for objects.

questions.q: Map and Set were introduced in:
questions.explanation: Map and Set are new collection types added in ES6.

questions.q: Which method is used to combine array elements into a single value?
questions.explanation: Array.prototype.reduce accumulates values into a single result.

questions.q: What is true about arrow functions and this?
options: They capture this from outer scope
questions.answer: They capture this from outer scope
questions.explanation: Arrow functions are lexically bound to the this of their surrounding scope.

questions.q: Which syntax creates a class in ES6?
questions.explanation: ES6 introduced the class keyword for constructor-based OOP.

questions.q: How do you create a Promise?
questions.explanation: A Promise is created with the new Promise(executor) syntax.

questions.q: Which method is used to handle a fulfilled Promise?
questions.explanation: then() is called when a Promise is fulfilled.

questions.q: Which array method returns a new array with elements that pass a condition?
questions.explanation: filter() keeps only elements where the callback returns true.

questions.q: Which array method transforms each element and returns a new array?
questions.explanation: map() applies a function to each element and returns a new array.

questions.q: Which statement is TRUE about const arrays?
options: You cannot reassign the whole array variable
questions.answer: You cannot reassign the whole array variable
questions.explanation: Elements can be modified, but the const variable cannot point to a new array.

questions.q: const x = { name: 'Ritaja' }; const y = { ...x }; x.name = 'Mounita'; console.log(y.name);
questions.explanation: Spread creates a shallow copy, so y is independent.

questions.q: let a = 10; { let a = 20; console.log(a); } console.log(a);
questions.explanation: Inner block has separate let variable.
Template literals allow expression evaluation.

questions.q: const arr = [1,2]; const newArr = [...arr, 3]; console.log(newArr);
questions.explanation: Spread appends elements.

questions.q: let x = 5; if (true) { let x = 7; } console.log(x);
questions.explanation: Inner let x is separate; outer x remains 5.

questions.q: const name = 'Kaustav'; const msg = `Hello ${name}!`; console.log(msg);
questions.explanation: Template literal inserts the value of name.

questions.q: const nums = [1,2,3]; const [a,b] = nums; console.log(a,b);
questions.explanation: First two elements are destructured into a and b.

questions.q: const student = { name: 'Susmita', city: 'Barrackpore' }; const {city} = student; console.log(city);
questions.explanation: Object destructuring extracts city property.

questions.q: const a = [1,2]; const b = a; b.push(3); console.log(a);
questions.explanation: a and b reference the same array.

questions.q: const a = [1,2]; const b = [...a]; b.push(3); console.log(a);
questions.explanation: Spread creates a new array; original a is unchanged.

questions.q: function show(name = 'Student'){ console.log(name); } show('Ritaja'); show();
questions.explanation: Default parameter is used only when no argument is passed.

questions.q: const centre = 'Coder & AccoTax'; const city = 'Barrackpore'; console.log(`${centre} - ${city}`);
questions.explanation: Template literal combines both variables.

questions.q: const marks = [80,90,100]; const [top, ...rest] = marks; console.log(top, rest);
questions.explanation: Here with [80,90,100], top=80 and rest=[90,100].

questions.q: console.log(0 ?? 50); console.log(null ?? 50);
questions.explanation: ?? only falls back for null or undefined, not for 0.

questions.q: const student = { name:'Pranjali' }; console.log(student.address?.city);
questions.explanation: Optional chaining returns undefined when address is missing instead of throwing error.

questions.q: const data = { scores:{ js:95 } }; console.log(data.scores?.js ?? 'NA');
questions.explanation: scores.js exists, so ?? returns 95.

questions.q: const teacher = { name:'Sukanta', greet(){ return 'Hello'; } }; console.log(teacher.greet?.());
questions.explanation: Optional chaining calls greet safely.

questions.q: const list = ['A','B','C']; for(const item of list){ console.log(item); }
questions.explanation: for...of iterates over each value.

questions.q: const arr = [1,2,3]; console.log(arr.map(n => n*2));
questions.explanation: map multiplies each element by 2.

questions.q: const arr = [1,2,3,4]; console.log(arr.filter(n => n % 2 === 0));
questions.explanation: filter keeps only even numbers.

questions.q: Create an arrow function that returns square of a number.
Use destructuring to extract city and phone from the object {name:'Kaustav', city:'Barrackpore', phone:7003}.
questions.solution: const student = {name:'Kaustav', city:'Barrackpore', phone:7003}; const { city, phone } = student;

questions.q: Write a function that merges two arrays using spread.
Convert this function to arrow: function greet(name){ return 'Hello '+name; }
Create an arrow function that returns the sum of two numbers.
Write a function using default parameters that prints 'Hello Student' when name is not provided.
Write code to destructure first and second elements from an array scores.
Destructure name and course from object {name:'Susmita', course:'ES6'} into variables n and c.
questions.solution: const { name: n, course: c } = {name:'Susmita', course:'ES6'};

questions.q: Create a new array allStudents by merging batch1 and batch2 using spread.
Use rest parameter to collect all arguments into an array named nums.
Create a function that logs 'Coder & AccoTax, Barrackpore' using a template literal.
Write a function printStudent({name, city}) using destructuring in parameters.
questions.solution: function printStudent({ name, city }) { console.log(name + ' - ' + city); }

questions.q: Write an arrow function that takes an array and returns a new array with each element doubled using map.
Create a short code snippet using optional chaining: console.log student.address.city safely.
Use nullish coalescing to assign defaultMarks as 50 if marks is null or undefined.
Write a small function that takes name and score and returns a template literal: `${name} scored ${score}`.
Write a function to clone an object student using spread.
Write a snippet that imports a named function getResult from './results.js'.
Write a snippet that exports a default arrow function sayHi.
Write a snippet that creates a class Student with a constructor(name) and a method greet().
questions.solution: class Student { constructor(name){ this.name = name; } greet(){ console.log('Hello ' + this.name); } }

questions.q: Write a function using rest parameters that returns sum of ANY number of values.
questions.solution: const sum = (...nums) => nums.reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0);

questions.q: Create a function that takes a student object and returns: "Name: X | City: Y" using template literals.
Use destructuring + spread to update a property inside nested object.
Fix the bug: const add = (a,b) => { a + b; }; // should return the sum
Fix the bug: const student = {name:'Ritaja', city:'Barrackpore'}; const {n, c} = student; // n and c should have name and city
questions.solution: const { name: n, city: c } = student;

questions.q: Fix the bug: const arr = [1,2,3]; const copy = arr; copy.push(4); // copy should not modify original
Write a function that safely reads user.profile.name using optional chaining.
Convert function Student(name){ this.name=name; } Student.prototype.greet = function(){ console.log('Hi '+this.name); } to an ES6 class.
questions.solution: class Student { constructor(name){ this.name = name; } greet(){ console.log('Hi ' + this.name); } }

questions.q: Create a small module studentService.js that exports getTopper as a named export and centre as a default export.
questions.solution: export function getTopper(list){ return list[0]; } const centre = 'Coder & AccoTax'; export default centre;

questions.q: Given const marks = [88,92,95,70], write a function using filter and map: keep marks >= 80 and then add 5 grace marks.
questions.solution: const processMarks = marks => marks.filter(m => m >= 80).map(m => m + 5);

projects.title: Student Result Formatter
projects.description: Create a result formatting module using export & import. Include student names like Ritaja, Devangshu, Susmita etc.

projects.title: Expense Combiner
projects.description: Combine multiple expense lists using spread and calculate totals.

projects.title: Teacher Directory Module
projects.description: Using default + named exports, maintain a list of teachers (e.g., Sukanta Hui, Tanusree Hui, Mounita Bhandari).

projects.title: Attendance Tracker with Rest & Spread
projects.description: Build a simple function markAttendance(teacher, ...students) that logs which teacher took attendance and which students were present.

projects.title: Batch Allocation Tool
projects.description: Use arrays, destructuring and spread to allocate students into different JavaScript batches at Coder & AccoTax.

projects.title: Marks Analyzer
projects.description: Given an array of marks, use map, filter and reduce to compute highest, lowest and average scores.

projects.title: Profile Card Generator
projects.description: Take a student object and create different string profiles using template literals and destructuring.

projects.title: Module-Based Utility Library
projects.description: Create multiple small files exporting helpers like add(), average(), formatName(), then re-export them from an index.js.

projects.title: Optional Chaining Safe Viewer
projects.description: Simulate an API response and use optional chaining to safely print nested fields like user.profile.address.city without runtime errors.

projects.title: Result Dashboard Skeleton
projects.description: Prepare a basic JS-only dashboard structure (no UI framework) where ES6 classes manage Student and Teacher data with modules and imports.
